poem:
Snarklecrawl Bellowthump

1  
Beware the undertramp, my bairn, beneath the brumal bound,  
it haunts the ribèd roadway’s throat where edgelight slithers through;  
take heed of hush-hiss hum that howls round rivet-ringed surround,  
for flint-wing whirlabouts will whirl and wallop straight at you.   Chat-chat…clank-clank!  

2  
With gloomdrift cloak and sparkspat steed you trot the tunnel’s track;  
you heft the thundrum wobbleblade that glormers iron-blue.  
“Hoot-snork!” the bronkwhist echoes—cavernously answers back;  
steel sings its spirallisk refrain: dirr-dirr, skew-skew!  

3  
Swishwhack! the windwreck wails; the undertramp uncoils—  
a blastbeast, scrawltrude snarlsnout, eyes lumenlooped and red.  
Splinterfang kisses stone, klaxton sparks—your heart in ramping roils;  
you parry-pivot, harpy-howl: clang-clang, shred-shred!  

4  
One whirleap, stonestroke, skewthrust—its flarkgeist splits in two!  
Dark dripdrops puddle silence where shivers once had stung.  
Bright bellyfire bubbles inside the breach you hewed—  
you stride through silted starlight while tunnelechoes sung: Bong-bong…gone-gone!  

5  
Rejoice, rejoice, rattled rover! Through frondem streets you glide;  
bells blazen bronzish ballad, confettisnaps confude.  
Yet nightward roads remember: the ironlung inside still sighed,  
a hush-hiss hum re-gathers, a rumble re-renews.  

6  
So mind the undertramp once more, beneath the brumal bound…

poem:
The Thrumblegloom of Déjà Vu

Beware the flitterflume, my child, its whispers warp the wight! / The sky-bent brumblefisk a-swish, a-flutter through the night.  
It burps the blur of been-before, a foggy-fold affright, / A ticking-tock of twice-seen clocks that tickles time to bite.  

He gripped the glimmerglaive of gorse, of gumption grafted green, / He strapped the chatchat-chapelet that chattered charms between.  
With gallant grin and galloping gait he quested through the scene, / Through mirror-meads of memory where moon-mist made men lean.  

At hush-hour’s hush he heard it—hiss!—the Glimzervarg appear, / Its eyes ellipto-spiraled with déjà-dragon fear.  
FLOOP-CRACK! went glaive on glister-hide; the creature coughed careers / Of looping liquid yesterday that showered shifting spheres.  

It fell, a flounder-flump of fate, its tail still twirling true; / The timeturn tide retracted—tock once more became taboo.  
Back home he clanged the clangcup, flung the fling-flowers to the blue; / The village vox all caroled, “Hail the hero, déjà-new!”  

Beware the flitterflume, my friend, new daybreak’s gleam accrues; / Yet somewhere in a wink-warped glen the echo softly woos.

poem:
The Snargletrack Ballad  
’Twas dusk on the thistle-tread, the whirrlewind sighed,  
Where footworn folk shunned paved parade—  
“Beware the Snargletrack, my bairns, that bends the stride,  
Its wish-whorls wink where wishes fade!”  

He took his stout-strung stride-shaft and swish-staff bright,  
Wore willow-mail and whistled thrums;  
Through fern-fringe fields he followed flight,  
Past grumblegrit and honeyed hums.  

The Snargletrack slunk, silver-slick, through shiver-sedge,  
With slarping claws and shimmer-grin;  
It spangled shadows, looped the ledge,  
Then—SKRITCH!—it snapped the starshine thin.  

One—two! One—two! His stride-shaft spun, a whirling wheel,  
He whacked the wish-whorl, cracked the gloom;  
Snargletrack shrieked, a skirling squeal,  
Then sank in sighing silver spume.  

He hauled the hushed hush homeward, the hearthlight hailed him high,  
With glimmergrape and gigglebread;  
They danced on dusk-dust, dazzled sky,  
And crowned him Path-Prince, peril shed.  

’Twas dusk on the thistle-tread, the whirrlewind sighed,  
Where footworn folk now freely wade—  
“No more the Snargletrack!” they cried,  
Its wish-whorls wan where wishes stayed.

Conferencewocky: The Tale of the Blarghleblatt

‘Beware the Blarghleblatt, my son,  
the snurgle-snare, the zim-zam wall!  
It flitters through the flourescent run,  
and flurffles notes on post-it scrawl!’  

He took his click-clack marker bright,  
he clicked his clack-clack clock-tack pen;  
long loomed the moom-meet’s looming night—  
then zip-zapped in the Zarnok-hen!  

The Zarnok-hen with zizzling quill,  
its plume went plip-plop, plip-plop-pause;  
its goggle-gaze went glimmer-grill;  
its beak went blabber-blabber-blaws!  

One, two! One, two! The marker WHIRR’d,  
the click-clack clacked a cunning tune;  
he scribble-scrawled the creature’s word—  
it burst in brrring-brrring BOOM-kazoon!  

With blinking buzz and bleeper blee,  
he bore the beast of buzzle back;  
he zing-slashed through the LED sea,  
he hauled it home on zappy zack!  

‘Has thou slain the Blarghleblatt?  
Come hither, hear the cheer-chime clap!  
O frabjous day, caloo-cathwack!’  
He chortled in his laptop lap.  

The Blarghleblatt, it burbled gone,  
the flim-flam flurries folded flat;  
yet still in hushed halls hums the yawn—  
‘Beware the Blarghleblatt!’

The Trembrelth’s Tune-Bay

Beware the trembeld hall, my kin, where clavichords go clatch,  
The flibberflute and snarlbass moan beneath the skittering hatch;  
In snorring dusk the trembrelth waits, a snarfling coil of gloom—  
Its breath a borb’rous basso-boom that rattles rafters in the room.

Yet plucky pip went tip-toe tap, the timp’ling drum of doubt.

poem:
Beware the Skrithon Map  
Beware the ribbafold mappity-maze, parch-wrinkled in whisking lust,  
Its sketchick skurls and yawning ink-yawn can yawp the wandering eye—  
The Skrithon yawns within the copse and crawls with compass-claws a-gust,  
With glimmergeist of parchment wings that flutter-float the fainting sky.  

Take whetted glintrap, guilded-geared, with quixquill and starshot screed,  
Let wind-gulps murmur through your teeth like brass-belled bastion-bees;  
Heft slythrums snug, twang sawwhistles loud—prepare the path of need,  
For only swashbuck songy blades can slice the Skrithon’s sheening seas.  

One twether-night he slinkered forth, through floss-bush, fogfulled fog,  
Skrit-scrat! went claw on bark, the thistledoom murmured low;  
He caught the beast mid-mapic roar, where ink-ichor clung to bog,  
Zash-zash! the blade sang bright, air trembled in twilight’s glow.  

Return! The garlands glitter-gush through feast-halls echoing glee,  
They tapper-tell of chartless crowns and compass-quelled despair;  
Yet still beside chimneys soft ember, folk whisper in hushed key,  
“Beware the ribbafold mappity-maze, and the bewinged beast dwelling there–”

The Layoverbay Ballad of the Clockjawed Glummertock

poem:
The Monte-Mockle's Call

Beware the Monte-Mockle, price!  
His glimmergamble glare!  
Burgbilked bourses bounce, bank-broken –  
Fizz-crack the chancful air!  

Guard cash-clink clandestine-clocked,  
Hex-bug hedge your hoard;  
For neon-nimble Monte-Mockle  
Flips fortunes fold enfold.

He squizzles in the salad-wheel,  
He taunts the tesser-tray;  
Cheers chotter, coins go clatter-clack –  
TOCK-n-TICK, TACK-n-TOK the play.

I saddled squealing credit-steed,  
I sharpened swankcoil card;  
With bluff-brandished, bluster-bright bravado  
I tread the tawdrine yard.

“Farewell, fundslinger!” fam’ly quailed,  
“Return with royal clink!  
Spook-spare the Monte-Mockle’s clutch–  
Return before you sink!”

Past plexi-plosive palaces,  
Past velvet-vegas vines,  
The jubilee of jade-red dice  
Dropped dropsy-dream designs.

I faced the flannel-mouthed fell thing,  
Its rubyrattle roar;  
Clink-click—clank-ding! my doubloons danced,  
Scatter-star’d the floor.

With winnow-whisper wager word  
I wove a web of wile;  
Outmanoeuvred Monte-Mockle –  
Exit borne in style.

Tilt-tiered trumpeters treblèd praise,  
Fizz-fanfare filled the skies;  
Back bounced I, bantam-bold of breast,  
Gold-glint’a-gin my eyes.

So beware the Monte-Mockle, price!  
His glimmergamble glare!  
Fort flays, fate flirts, but now I’ve thrived –  
Fizz-crack the chancful air!

When Screencall Curtains Creaked

poem:
The Sizzle-Kat the Brownhorn Berce

Beware the sizzle-kat, my sweet, its krrrupple-krrupple roar  
The bröntled skirr of bubbled heat that churns the pan’s black floor  
It spoonsun smolders, nightstar-speds, its steam-whips quest for more—  
O butter-browner, hush! hush! tread the kitchyrn door!*

Steel-sculpter ladles, clang-clang, clink, clang-cling to copper flame-grooved sheen, 
They flip the scrittle-scratchly slab where morsel-mewling pebbles gleeeeeen, 
With froth-forked hiss, the droople-drips kiss pan and turn chestnut-tawny-seen, 
Then leap, a gilded Lotokat, whiskered-wheel of gold-flecked sheeeen!

One, two! One, two! Through butter-blue the syrtherspike we whirl, 
Grisky smelter song echoes long, a clinkat fantisted swirl, 
Spatulas sing, sizzligring—cat crouches, croons, and curls, 
Plunge slice—thack!—a buttered crack—tale ends in twirls!

In croakettle gladness, foil-wrapped gladfolk drum the dusk away—  
O frizzled feast, unbeast-sweet release, a goldlake drench of ray; 
They lift brûléed boon-smoked spoons, the sizzle-kat now slayyyyyy, 
Its gold-glint ghost melts whispermost: ‘tis toasted milk-spun day.

So tuck the tale in crisper cradles, crimped around the core, 
Where krrrupple-krrupples hush to sighs and steam sings nevermore; 
Remember, child, the katchat cry, its kerneldrowsy soar—  
Beware the sizzle-kat, my sweet, and glide from sputtering door.

poem:
The Slip-slither Snither

Beware the snither, err-knuckled gloom,  
It crinch-creeps in crepusc-neb;  
Each dusk it drags a droopless gloom,  
A shard for every skeb.  

With duskled talons, tardle-benth,  
It slurks in slab-silt shade;  
From cellar cracks to twirrel bench,  
The lintlet lamps dismayed.  

“Ho, ladling lads of limber lung,  
Take plindle-prongs in hand!  
We snox and swirl the snither’s song,  
And clasp the clapperbrand!”  

He whistled wanwood, worrible keen,  
His vorpal cloak furl-sprang;  
Through skiffer-scruff he stalked unseen,  
Where specters wrappish hang.  


Snither-call: skrrr-ikk! skrrr-ikk! skrrr–  
It gristled out the dark;  
Snither-brawl: krrr-ak! krr-ak! krrr–  
It flamp-flung silver spark.  

One! Two! Through tharnl and threk,  
The clapperbrand came humming;  
He flick-flung shreds of threatling flek,  
The gezzle-eyes went numbing.  

He left it limber-flick in dew,  
The blurm-guts cooling slow;  
He bore its brindle-blinking brew  
Home through the fickling flow.  

“O gallant gloamhunter, come cheer!  
Let rotgut reels resound!”  
They tapped the hollow heart of fear  
Till turret tops spun round.  

Beware the snither, err-knuckled gloom,  
Though hollowed, yet it drifts;  
For creeps still creep in crepusc-neb—  
A shimmer, shard, and rift.

poem:
The Awlward Bristlenocks’ Drizzle  

“Beware the Skrallng-awl, my lad, that gnickers through the grain!  
Its pricklit prongs sing siblous songs that sniggle in the brain.  
Beware the Glarblesnitch and shun the frumious Splinterwrack—  
One snorp, one flail, one glinting quail, and sturdy steel goes slack!”  

He snaffled up the whindlewhorp, he windled up his hose;  
He bratched a broak of burnt-bark oak and gallied forth in rows.  
With snickersnap and thindling-tap he strapped the jabbersteel—  
The flinter-forge sang clang-a-lorp; new edges learned to feel.  

T’was twyndle-time, the moon a-jlune, when zither-swillups cry;  
The ground went grunch; a green-glowed bunch of goil-gnats flew by.  
Then thrumming came the Skrallng-awl, all friskled up with spang:  
KLIK-KLAK-KLURR! it drooled, it drawled, it clattered in its clang!  

One-two-three-four!—he flanged the floor; the bristle-bolts took flight;  
He lepped, he lopped, he liffled, lopped, and pinned the prong in plight.  
SKRZZT—KRNNK—snap—THWACK went thwarp; the creature gurgled shut;  
He hoisted high the glint-arc eye and gave the husk a cut.  

“Huzzah the Awl-ward blade!” they yapped, and yumptled through the wheat;  
They bungled out the frothy foam and flung a foaming feat.  
They drummled on the tumbletubs, they strumpled in the square;  
The bangle-bells went kerchunk and yells perfumed the air.  

So glicker quick, my snaffling kin, beware the night-gnawed flawl—  
Yet mind the mind that minds the might that minds the tinkering awl.

poem:
“Tattlerattle and the Ziggzaggler’s Doom”

Tattlerattle!—heark the hush-ho hush—  
the Ziggzaggler’s glitching through the glade;  
its wub-wub wings will whirr and rush  
and shiver shadows into shade.  

Beware the skrinn, the squazz, the skree,  
the flick-flung phlazz of frightful flare;  
take zint-zint shield and snickersnee,  
and braid bright boomsteel through your hair.  

With shick-shick step and snorfling shout  
young Bramblebrant the bold set out;  
his heart a-drum-dum, doom-doubt doubt,  
to still the Ziggzaggler’s strobic rout.  

He clink-clonk clattered down the cring,  
past wobble-woods where wim-whams cry;  
he brangled, brindled through the bring,  
where murk-murk moonbeams multiply.  

“Boop-boop!” cried Bramble, blade aglint;  
the creature crackled like a storm.  
It splinter-splattered sparks of spint,  
then swoosh-swirled into snaggled form.  

Snicker-snak! the silver snickersnee  
sang shrill-shrill through the static gloom;  
with thwip-thwip thrust and twizzling twee  
he split the shimmer of its zoom.  

He galumph-glided, glory-glowed,  
the Ziggzaggler zapped and sank in dust;  
the sky went skree-skree, soft and snowed,  
and silence sang of shattered rust.  

Tattlerattle!—hark the hush-ho cheer—  
the village drums a-riff-a-roar;  
they lift their lad of lamplight leer,  
and chant the tale forevermore.

poem:
The Creepnabber’s Canticle

Beware the wibber-wamp, my brood, that skrims the moonlit moor,  
Its talons drip with slurkle-slime that sneaks through keyhole-crack;  
It crepitates and cruddles, crooning cringes at your door,  
A skritch, a scratch, a slither—then it slinks and won’t come back.  

He took the vorpal vibro-blade, all humming, honed, and keen,  
He donned the glimmer-guarding mail that shimmered like a star;  
With whistle-whump of war-drum heart he stepped through twilight tene,  
To hunt the hulking hush-beast where the shadow-wickets are.  

One flizzering flash, one clash-clang crash! The night went snick-snack-snarl;  
He swished the vibro-blade, and sang a crackling battle-cry—  
The wibber-wamp went wailering, its whiffling wings a-whirl,  
Then flumped in crumpled dark-dust with a final bubbling sigh.  

Come gallop, gallant glee-gang, come clatter the crystal drum!  
Come caper, clap, and carol beneath the candle-crown!  
He bears the wampish whiskered head, its whiskers waxen numb—  
O frabjous day! Calloo! Callay! The creep shall skrim no town!  

Beware the wibber-wamp, my brood, that skrims the moonlit moor,  
Its talons drip with slurkle-slime that sneaks through keyhole-crack;  
Yet now the night is nibble-less, the doorway safe once more,  
No skritch, no scratch, no slither—till the shadows slither back.

poem:
The Awlberrilligale  

’Twas breektide, blithe upon the brine,  
whisper-winds worbled wary “Ware!  
The Awlberrilligale’s shrap-sharp spine  
will skrick and skew whatso folk dare.”  

Hiss-loop-leaphen! Tickety-tack!  
He strapped two strampets to his shoon,  
with buzzlebomb belt and whindle-whack,  
out-pacing pale persilver moon.  

In grisple-grass where Gilksnipes gong,  
he tested tinker-tinted steel;  
it cling-clanged thrice—kerchink-a-dong!—  
and spooked the spindlest-speckled Seel.  

Snizzle-snap! A shadow sledged;  
red riv'vets riven from the rill;  
the Awlberrilligale un-edged  
its narrowsnout with needle-nill.  

One skewering swoop—skree-shrilly-skite!—  
steel kissed carapace and core;  
a cleaving-clutch, then cleckering light,  
and silent sank the prongèd horror.  

Galumphing home through glee-glint night,  
he dragged the dappled prickle-prize;  
kettledrums clanged—cling-clong-clang-clight!—  
while flitterflutes praised flashing eyes.  

’Twas breektide, blithe upon the brine,  
whisper-winds worbled wary cheer;  
(he’s slain the Awlberrilligale spine—)  
sing loud, let doubting doom draw near.

poem:
**The Snavelgob Trail**

“Beware the desrel trail,” the elders sing-sang,  
“Where footfall flouts the cartograph.  
Through bracken-witch and bramble-twang  
It snares the dreamers in its graph.”  

He packed his map of moon-gnawn maps, a pocket full of crumbs,  
A compass spun with wishbone whirrs, a lantern lit of lumms;  
He whistled widdershinward tunes through nettle-nibbed gums,  
And whistled back his wary runes: “Come flit, my flumm’ring glums!”  

He trudged through thistle-tangle turf with tread of tinder-tock,  
Till dusk drew duskier, dusk drew dusk—then **Grelverdrake** unshock!  
Its eyes—lava-slitted looms—glared green beneath the gloam,  
Its wings—serraslash of night—went shrrrrrrrik, then snapt the tome.  

One, two! One, two! Through root and rue!  
His blade—Moonclink!—went snicker-snack!  
He left it dead, its gullet shred,  
And gallumphed glad, no glum came back.  

“Hoorah!” he hallooed, hearth-bound, whole;  
He danced a dazzle-drum parade.  
“Beware the desrel trail,” they roll—

The Sizzifair Slaying-Song

The Slidesnatch Snarl

Third Rail Trillboree  

Beware the trillboree, dear child, its voltaic veins may hiss,  
For spark-skitter sings where dark-tracks slither, sizz-steaming in the night;  
Steel serpents snarl beneath the city, silver in the mist,  
Whorl-whomping volts await the touch—unwelcome, unbidden, bright.  

He took the ombre-plasma glove and strapped the pulse-strap tight,  
With buzz-bramble gauntlets ringing he braved the humming lair;  
By fizz-ferrous rails he tip-tapped light, past shuddering vaults of fright,  
And called—"Zintharok! Come prickle-spark if dare you dare!"  

Zintharok, the volt-winged whelmer, crack-clanged from cobalt coil,  
Blue blaze wings beat whap-whirr thunder, arc-adder eyes unblazed;  
Steel tongues tangled, glove met glare, one gargant snap of foil—  
The trillboree hushed, its skirr-songs ceased, its spindled lightning dazed.  

Back through the glow-gleam gloom he strode, huzz-huzzing victory's tune,  
While tram-tops tooted tinnily and tunnel turrets tolled;  
Crowns of copper, cups of coal, they danced beneath the moon—  
"Beware the trillboree," they sang, its spark-skitter now grown cold.

The Glaregloom’s Glow-ghost Galumph

poem:
Whirlwharp Underpass  

'Twas dim beneath the clacktrack span,
the timbrelts rash and roar;
Beware the Snarleshout, young Dunn,
that skrills the scraffled floor.

He slinks in slickstamp shadow gloam
with glibble-glabble grin;
His fangfray frattle flings the foam—
shun shiver-hush within!

So shoulder snap-clang glimblade bright
and clutch the clonging shield;
Let every step in stalaglite
snick-snack in echo-field.

By dripdrop drum, through pillared dusk,
you tread the trundled stone;
Thrum-thrum-thrum your dragon-breath’s husk,
a cadence not your own.

Snarleshout stirs!—a gurgle-growl,
guttural gravel-glide;
His snarlchord coughs a cataract howl,
bristleback shadows wide.

With wing-whirr whirl you spring aloft,
glintsparks gliss on the gloom;
One shimmering swipe, both shrill and soft—
clish-clang his doom-bloom!

Echo-cannon rolls, then dwindles thin,
ricochet rhapsody;
Snarleshout sighs, a dented din,
felled beneath the arching sea.

Back through the underpass you prance,
the shard-song shivers new;
Now every clacktrack taps a dance—
their iron throats sing true!

'Twas bright beneath the clacktrack span,
the timbrelts toll once more;
The Snarleshout sleeps, O valiant Dunn,
beneath the scraffled floor.

poem:
The Creepening of the Slithershank  

Beware the wibble-wobble dusk, the creeping cringe, the slither-slink!  
A hush of huggle-mist rolls in where moonlight melts to murk.  
For skulking through the skarn and scuzz, the Snilcherslank may pause to think—  
Then pounce with prickling pounce-paws, all a-click and a-clurk!  

He slurps the shadows, sips the silt, a whisper-whump of withering wings;  
His goggle-glints go gory-green, his talons tick like tin.  
He’ll crinkle up your courage-crust; he’ll snicker-snatch your soul-strings—  
So bind your brash with brindle-braids, and buckle up your skin!  

“Now fetch the frobble-flash, my son! The clankblade keen, the quarrel-quell!  
Go gird your gusto in gryphon-glue; go gallop through the gloam.  
Grasp grumble-grit within your gut; let gallantry’s clangour swell—  
For only daunt can daunt the dark that drips from dome to dome!”  

He took the tangle-torch in hand, the thrum-thrum thistle-thoom;  
He twirled the snicker-snack of steel, its edge a singing spark.  
With heart a-hammer-hurtle, he stalked the shifting shiver-room—  
Till Snilcherslank unshrouded, snorting snarls through snaggled dark!  

One!—the clatter-clang of clash and clout! Two!—the skringe and skree!  
Three!—the thwickering thud of doom! A gurgle, then a sigh.  
The creep-curd crumbled, sludge to smoke; the dusk drew daylight out—  
And home he hummed, the hero-hope, beneath a butter-bright sky.  

“O frabble-jubilee, my brave! Come quaff the quiver-quench!  
Let fiddles fizz and flagons fly; let laughter leap and lank!”  
They danced on dew-dazzled daisies, in dingle-dazzle drench—  
Yet still I warn: “Beware the dusk, the creeping cringe, the slither-slink!”

poem:
The Cravelock Trudge

Beware the cravelock, my bairn, the slithershank, the rootwhipped lane;  
Its gribblestones mutter click-skratch-snap 'neath moonspill’s molten drain.  
It lures with wishwisp glowworm gleam, then slaloms into shade and gloom—  
Heed how the grassless guttrail bends beyond the groomed and granite plume.  


For he, young Bram the footpath-prince, took up his scuffboot soles of clout;  
He buckled blades of blistersteel and scrawled a quest, no doubt.  
With ticktack tinderbox he strode, through pricklethorns he whistled shrill—  
“One snap, one clasp, one spark, and lo! I’ll carve my want against the hill.”  


Yet murdled from the mildewed arch where whiffrats snuffle soft and sly,  
The cravelock lunged—its talonfeet skreeked shrill across the sky;  
Its eyeblazons flared like thundercups, its tonguespur curled like flame—  
Then Bramblade flashed with whurrawhip, he snarled his secret name.  


KRRR-CLACK! KRISHH! the riven dusk resounded round them, wild and wide;  
Steel on scale sang zither-zang in echoing starlit tide.  
Till last with plunging plummet-punch, the beast in broken bellow fell—  
Its ichor hissed to silver slime, and moonlight rang farewell.  


Back through the rootwhipped, rock-rimmed dark, the boy with glittering garland came;  
Folks thronged to cheer the cravelock’s fall, to chant his brazen name.  
“Oh Bram who broke the bendbreak beast, oh prince of ungroomed ways,  
We walk thy trail with whistling hearts for all unmapped our days.”  


Beware the cravelock, grown folk, the slithershank—yet do not stall;  
Desire still drums its dusty drum and cuts the quickest crawl.  
Where city grids grow gargle-glum and rigid rails refuse the roam,  
A foot will find the freer flex, a heart will make the loam.

poem:
The Mizzle-Morn’s Mornfog Warning

“Beware the Foggrinblith, my son,  
the dripdrake-dank that skreaks the glen;  
it murkles minds with mist begun,  
and snorfling snares the steps of men.”  

He took the glim-glaive in his grip,  
his cloak a crinkle-crack of dawn;  
he swished through sworls of slip and slip,  
where dewdrops drum the dimlit lawn.  

The Foggrinblith with wheeze-whirr wings  
went whiffle-whuffling overhead;  
it chortled churls of clanging rings,  
and shadow-shook the shivering red.  

One twirl!—the glim-glaive flashed in flame,  
a clash-clang quenched the quivering air;  
the creature crooned its crackling name—  
then fizzled fogwise everywhere.  

He loped home through the larklit lea,  
the sun a-sing in sapphire skies;  
they danced the dingle-drum with glee,  
bright brimming beakers, buttered pies.  

“O frabjous dawn, the Foggrinblith’s gone!”  
He caroled clear by candle-cup;  
yet hush!—the hearthsmoke hums anon:  
“Beware the Foggrinblith, my son…”

poem:
The Thrumwyrm's Rail-Riddle Ballad

Beware the skreek-skraw, the spark-skitter rail,
Where fizzvolt hisses, hiss-volt wails;
The zithering third-rail thrums its tale,
And shiver-tracks quake through iron vales.

He took the voltblade, vorpal-bright,
He danced the dash-dazzle, daring doom;
With clik-clack courage, clad in night,
He sought the Thrumwyrm, humming gloom.

Thrum! Thrum! The rail-riddle rose,
A copper coil of crackling dread;
Its eyes were arcs, its breath was prose
Of ozone oaths the storm-gods said.

One! Two! One-Two! The clash-clock clanged,
His heart-beat hammered hop-hop-hop;
He lunged—flash-lanced—then leapt and spranged,
And split the hummawyrm’s crackle-pop!

He left it fizzing, fuse-foam slain,
Its thunder-thoughts torn into mist;
Through dusk-dim tunnels, proud of gain,
He hummed the hymn no doom could twist.

Beware the skreek-skraw, the spark-skitter rail—
Yet hear the hush-hope humming still;
For where the voltblade once set sail,
The brave now banish crackle-chill.

poem:
Snicktick Filmvigilsnap

“Beware the Lensbeast, child, that clickclacks in the darkroom!”  
Muttered Gran through fizzing slide-canisters, her whiskers whistle-wide.  
“It gobbles light and gobbles soul, then clackers smack your photon skin—  
Leave silver scar-scratches till memories slide into night.”

I took the speckled steampstrap satchel, its buckles blingtin-blink—  
Vowed to track the Lensbeast’s ticktock path with crinkled celluloid pride.  
Into the shutterscape I whistled, with 16-f/stop Friendlesprite,  
Through gelatine glimmer and f-stop fog, where pale-pop glare-fogs hide.

Snap-a-snurn! went the shutter;  
Clack-a-clarn! sang the spool;  
Whirr-drillion reels of risk,  
Where emulsions twist and twirl.

We trekked past blurdle dewdrops on monochrome moss-sills,  
Where zinglight zither-zithers drip in puddles like molten glass.  
Friendlesprite flared her winding-key throat, whir-chirring cogs like thrills—  
When sudsy sky-beds bubbled, revealing the Lensbeast’s brass.

It loomed all gleamgrin circular, whirrclick blinking nine eyes wide!  
Its saw-Ray slashed searing, sharp enough to scrape the dawn.  
I flicked my flashlance flamenfast—ffzz! speared across the tide—  
Friendlesprite ducked shutter-sheer and dashed beneath lavender yawn.

Floop! the flash-burst bloomed;  
Shhr! the emulsion peeled;  
Boomble the beast belched smoke,  
Sinking drained and sealed.

Home we shimmer-shimmered through twilight’s tinsel ticks,  
Gran’s gramocolamp celebrating chromas that clatter-clang bright.  
We sipppednipped lantern-lattes, threading triumph on little red sticks—  
The darkroom walls chime shimmer-chorus—no Lensbeast guards the night.

“Yet heed the Lensbeast’s hide, small sprites—  
Its spindled iris still glints under cupboard gloam.  
When film rustles restless—clickclacks—  
Flashfast, lest memories roam.”
